article.title: Accretion onto young stars: the key to disk evolution

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the cyan line in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The photospheric template of the target star.
The best fit for the continuum emission of the target star.
The accretion shock model used to fit the target spectrum.
The interstellar extinction curve applied to the target spectrum.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the double power-law fit (black solid line) in Figure 2 suggest about the relationship between mass accretion rate and stellar mass?
choices: The relationship is linear across all stellar masses.
The relationship is steeper for lower mass stars.
The relationship is shallower for lower mass stars.
There is no correlation between mass accretion rate and stellar mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general trend observed in Figure 3 regarding the relationship between disk mass and stellar mass?
choices: Disk mass decreases linearly with increasing stellar mass.
Disk mass increases linearly with increasing stellar mass.
Disk mass increases more steeply than linear with increasing stellar mass.
There is no correlation between disk mass and stellar mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the black dot-dashed lines in Figure 4, representing M_disk/M_acc values from 0.1 to 10 Myr?
choices: They indicate the expected range for viscous timescale in these disks.
They demonstrate that all observed disks are evolving viscously.
They illustrate the lack of correlation between disk mass and accretion rate.
They highlight the significant role of external photoevaporation in these systems.
